alcohol and smoking - Health</topcClas>         <topcClas>Social attitudes and behaviour - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Youth - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Smoking, Drinking and Drug Use among Young People</i> survey series began in 1982, under the name <i>Smoking among Secondary Schoolchildren</i>.  The series initially aimed to provide national estimates of the proportion of secondary schoolchildren aged 11-15 who smoked, and to describe their smoking behaviour. Similar surveys were carried out every two years until 1998 to monitor trends in the prevalence of cigarette smoking. The survey then moved to an annual cycle, and questions on alcohol consumption and drug use were included. The name of the series was accordingly changed to <i>Smoking, Drinking and Drug Use among Young Teenagers</i> to reflect this widened focus. In 2000, the series title changed, to <i>Smoking, Drinking and Drug Use among Young People</i>. The survey has been carried out every year in England since 2000 by the National Centre for Social Research (now NatCen Social Research) and the National Foundation for Educational Research. From 2005, the Information Centre for Health and Social Care (from 2013 the Health and Social Care Information Centre) took over from the Department of Health as sponsors.  <br> <br> In alternate survey years, beyond the core questions, the remainder of the questionnaire focuses on either smoking and drinking or on drug taking. The 2001, 2003, 2005, 2007, 2009  and 2011 surveys focused mainly on drugs, and the 2000, 2002, 2004, 2006, 2008, 2010 and 2012 surveys focused mainly on smoking and drinking.  It should be noted that the UK Data Archive holds the survey only from 1988 onwards.<br> <br> In some years, the surveys have been carried out in Scotland and Wales, as well as England, to provide separate national estimates for these countries. In 2002, following a review of Scotland's future information needs in relation to drug misuse among schoolchildren, a separate Scottish series (see under GN 33354) was established by the Scottish Executive.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract>The <i>Survey of Smoking, Drinking and Drug Use among Young People in England in 2013</i> is the latest in a series of surveys that measures the prevalence of smoking cigarettes, drinking alcohol and illicit drug use among 11 to 15 year olds in England. The survey collects detailed prevalence data as well as associated contextual information, including relevant attitudes, beliefs and knowledge. As well as a core set of questions that are included every year, the questionnaire alternates its focus between smoking and drinking (every other year between 2000 and 2012) and drug taking (every other year between 2001 and 2013).</abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Main topics included:<ul><li>young people in England and their legal and illegal substance use</li><li>associated attitudes, beliefs and knowledge.</li></ul></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2013-09-01T00:00:00Z">September 2013</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2013-12-01T00:00:00Z">December 2013</collDate>         <nation>England</nation>         <geogUnit>Government Office Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Secondary school pupils in England in Years 7 to 11, during 2013.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Biannually since 1982, annually since 1998.</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>National Centre for Social Research</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>5,189 pupil records</deviat>         <collMode>Self-completion</collMode>         <sources>           <dataSrc>The NFER database of schools, which contained information supplied by the Department for Education, was used.</dataSrc>         </sources>         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply.
